However, when I came across this comment, I thought it would be perfect to get your attention for a topic that applies to every single person reading this, regardless of whether you’re a 24-year-old college graduate or a 70-year-old who retired a few years ago.

That comment was posted under a recent Wall Street Journal article about a new retirement formula, which obviously got my attention, as retirement investing has become a much bigger part of my coverage here on Seeking Alpha in recent years.

The article was about finding a new way to assess how much risk someone can afford to take. It was basically written to improve some of the ideas that have been out there for ages, including the traditional 60/40 idea and the rule where we subtract our age from 100 to find out how much equity exposure we should take.

In my case, that number would be 70% equities, as I’m 30. For my parents, who turn 58 this year, that number would be just 42%. The 70-year-old I just used in my example would have just 30% exposure, which brings me back to the comment at the top of my article. Assuming the 70-year-old is a male, there’s a statistical chance of more than 40% he makes it to age 90, according to the JPMorgan data in the chart below.

You may know where I’m going with this. For starters, the comment on top isn’t just funny but also true, at least to a certain extent. It is still very easy to end up with money problems if you become too conservative at 70. If you’re blessed with a long life, which is obviously a good thing, you may have to cover at least two more decades of spending.

Today, I will discuss these situations and why we seriously need to rethink retirement investing.

So, before this intro gets out of hand, let’s get to it!

It’s Time To Rethink Retirement

In general, whenever we discuss retirement strategies, the problem is that every situation is unique. So many times when I cover higher-yielding stocks, some people bring up the fact that if we start investing in growth stocks early enough, we may not even need high-yield stocks.

I know that, but imagine if I wrote articles telling people who are required to buy higher-yielding stocks because of limited funds to just go back 30 years and make smarter life choices? I would become the most hated financial writer.

Even the example of the 70-year-old I just used is flawed. After all, if he were to retire with $200,000 in his investment account, which would pay him $20,000 in pre-tax income at a 10% yield, or retire with $2 million in the bank is a huge difference. With $2 million, you can reasonably expect to get $80,000 in income from a conservative 4% income portfolio.

If you also decide to sell some principal, you’re all set, especially if we include Social Security payments.

So, there’s obviously more to it than one’s age.

This brings me back to the Wall Street Journal article. The article was based on a 47-page (including the appendix) research paper that covered just how unrealistic many formulas for retirement investing are:

Research on normative household financial choices almost always gives quantitative guidance in one of two forms: a simple formula for an unrealistic setting, or numerical solutions for only a few parameter sets in a realistic setting. We propose a middle-ground approach we call practical finance: analytic approximations to optimal solutions as a function of relevant parameters in realistic settings that are easily computed in a spreadsheet. We provide such an approximation for lifecycle portfolio choice with labor income. Across 5,103 parameter sets, our approximation results in welfare that is on average only 0.06% lower than that of the optimal solution.- Choi et al. 2025

Essentially, the research is about a formula that also looks into one’s income, savings, and risk tolerance. Especially the risk tolerance is key, as I am someone who takes much bigger risks than average without losing sleep. Meanwhile, I know people who couldn’t handle investing in simple index funds. Everyone is different, as obvious as that may sound.

One big factor is that we may have to spend more time on “safe assets.” According to the report, we don’t put enough weight on personal income (paychecks) and future retirement income. Essentially, this is bond-like income that doesn’t fluctuate with the stock market.

Obviously, there are situations where that isn’t the case, like in my situation (working in finance), but, in general, that’s bond-like income. Essentially, future earnings and Social Security are a floating-rate bond that needs to be incorporated in investment decisions.

Think about it, if you have that kind of income/safety, why would you add another layer of safety in your investment portfolio?

For example, a 25-year-old with a $70 thousand annual income should, according to Choi’s formula, be 100% in stocks. That’s above traditional formulas, including the ones we just discussed:

Moreover, it’s important to keep your existing net worth into account. For example, a middle-aged couple aged 50 with a combined income of $160 thousand would have a 53% “recommended” equity position if they had $800 thousand in investable net worth compared to $400 thousand.

Here’s why that is:

But it recommends a much lower allocation, 53%, when the couple has twice as much money to invest, because in that scenario upping the equity allocation would alter the risk profile of a larger proportion of their projected lifetime resources.

“It’s more conservative when you have more money saved up,” Choi said. - WSJ

I also love the inclusion of risk tolerance (see below). Some investors can take more risks than others, as I already briefly mentioned. That’s why the model makes the case that a 70-year-old with a high-risk tolerance can easily have 64% in equities, based on an annual income of $72 thousand and a $1 million net worth. I absolutely agree with that.

With that said, I also played around with the spreadsheet that was provided by the researchers (it’s mentioned in the WSJ article. I won’t give you a direct link, as it refers to Google Sheets).

I found that a lot depends on risk aversion and one’s expected stock market return. The base numbers seem to use a real (after-inflation) return of 5.0% per year. When adjusting that number to 7.0%, even most risk-averse portfolios for higher-aged people are geared toward overweight equity positions.

Again, I think that is a much better way to look at it, as it makes much better use of one’s financial capabilities, expectations, and bond-like income for cash flows.

Although one can (and maybe should) make the case that AI increases labor uncertainty, this model seems the best approach to me, as people with a high-risk tolerance are simply leaving dollars on the table if they become conservative too fast, especially if they enjoy the safety of a high (future) income.

I think because time is our best asset (it’s finite, even for billionaires), we should focus way more on that instead of on basic allocation formulas and the obvious fact that bonds are less volatile than stocks. Less volatile doesn’t mean less risky if we look into potential lost opportunities on a long-term basis.

Now What?

In this part, I’m generalizing a lot. That may be obvious, but I still want to emphasize that none of this is personal financial advice. As I said, every situation is unique.

I believe in equities. That’s because I dislike bonds, as I simply prefer to buy ownership in actual companies that I trust. Moreover, while I own a few non-dividend-paying stocks, my goal is always to invest in companies that will, over time, provide steadily-growing dividends. Historically speaking, that’s where we buy alpha with a highly favorable volatility/risk profile, as the data below shows.

So, for the 25-year-old age group, I think 100% equities makes sense. Here, I would focus on 0.00% to 2.0% yield with a double-digit growth profile. For example, Visa (V), Broadcom (AVGO), Old Dominion Freight Line (ODFL), Carlisle Companies (CSL), Amazon (AMZN), and Alphabet (GOOGL). All of these are companies with competitive moats, low AI disruption risks (although Alphabet could fall behind if its AI models lack innovation), and secular growth tailwinds.

Generally speaking, these companies focus more on reinvesting capital than on distributing it to shareholders. When combined with attractive risk/rewards and stellar capital allocation track records, these are the companies you cannot own enough of if you’re still four decades or so away from retirement.

Also note that I am not talking about ultra-high growth stocks here, like the ones that people were buying in 2021. I believe these speculative stocks have no place in serious portfolios unless we keep the exposure to less than 10%. After all, the future flows of salary are a reason to take risks, but not an excuse to change the risk/reward of the entire portfolio.

I often use the ARK Innovation ETF (ARKK) as a proxy for these stocks:

This may sound obvious, but you would be surprised how many portfolios I encounter among young people that are filled with growth stocks that all depend on very specific developments to make their valuations work.

Ideally, if you do this for 25 to 30 years, you don’t have to make any changes. Assuming you’re really good at picking stocks, you now own companies with such high yields on cost that you can retire based on these alone.

However, for many, changing situations require changed portfolios.

If you’re over 50, depending on an average income, the equity exposure recommendation drops to 76% (based on $400 thousand net worth) and 53% ($800 thousand net worth). These are the examples I just used based on Choi’s formula.

For this situation, more mature dividend growers are perfect. Here, I would aim for yields of 2.5% to 4.0% with companies that have wide moats and a mix of cyclical and anti-cyclical growth.

Think about The Williams Companies (WMB), PepsiCo (PEP), Union Pacific (UNP), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Lockheed Martin (LMT), and Exxon Mobil (XOM). Essentially, these are many of the holdings of the Schwab US Dividend Equity ETF (SCHD).

In other words, to use ETFs as a proxy, we have seen this transition:

  • 20/25 years old until 50—Capital Group Dividend Value ETF (CGDV)
  • 50 until 70 (retirement)—Schwab US Dividend Equity ETF.

For my parents, I am running a strategy combining these two, as they own SCHD-like stocks that dominate their portfolio and some CGDV-like growth stocks to improve alpha and incorporate their age and income safety profile. The older they get, the more we will shift to income and safety, although we are unlikely to go into high bond positions due to the pensions they will receive. Using Choi’s logic, it would be a waste of capital to become too defensive if we don’t have to.

Now, the next stage is retirement. Again, ideally, if you’re 70 and have invested for 50 years, even moderate successes may have led to a high net worth. For example, investing $500 per month for 45 years at 7% (I went with 10% nominal and 3% inflation) turns into $1.7 million without any initial investment.

If you have a net worth that high, you can massively reduce risk. If you don’t have a high net worth (like the majority of your peers), you may have to focus on generating higher income. In that case, I would prioritize REITs and midstream stocks, which, in general, are two of my favorite places to buy income.

Here, boring is good. Think about 5% to 8% income from stocks like NNN REIT (NNN), Realty Income (O), ONEOK (OKE), Enbridge (ENB), and Energy Transfer (ET). The last one here is an MLP that issues a K-1 form.

All of these are companies with >70% payout ratios where the focus is on income. And while none of them have stock prices that are immune to recessions and other sell-offs, they all have highly predictable revenue and income.

A Few Notes On My Own Situation

Now, my personal situation is complex, and I’m, once again, breaking most rules.

  • I have 100% of my liquid net worth in equities.
  • I have no debt.
  • Although I will pay rent until September, I will have a paid-off primary residence by then, which I expect to accelerate in value at no less than 10% per year.
  • I’m 30 (as I already mentioned)
  • I’m not a millionaire yet (very close, though), but I have a high net worth for my age group, which is key for the formula.
  • I have no major safety nets (i.e., unemployment and retirement support from the government)

My income is very risky, as I have multiple projects/businesses going on, none of which result in highly predictable cash flows. Generally speaking, the research we discussed makes the case that I should own a lot of defensive stocks. However, I mostly own aggressive dividend (growth) stocks.

This is a risk I am taking because I want to use the current market environment to my advantage and because I believe the timing for cyclical value stocks is right. However, I always have a higher-income plan in mind, as I often discuss here on Seeking Alpha.

If needed, I can rapidly transition to income to protect my expenses.

The biggest risk I am taking is getting into a spot where the stock market craters, erasing a big part of my net worth, which will make it much harder to generate a decent income.

I am essentially betting on my risk profile and ability to turn above-average returns into a strong nest egg as soon as possible. I’m essentially trying to do the whole FIRE movement as a speedrun. I’ll obviously keep readers up to date on this.

For now, this is the takeaway:

Takeaway

Retirement planning is a highly challenging thing, as every situation is unique.

Today, we discussed some new findings that shed some light on important factors that tend to have a huge impact on equity exposure. This includes our expected income, risk aversion, and expected returns. Without these factors, I think traditional methods are useless.

Although I am breaking most of these rules, given that I run more risks than I should, I am essentially banking on my expected returns and risk awareness. That doesn’t work for everyone, which is why we discussed suitable investments for various age brackets.

I think by following some of these basic rules, we can do two things:

  • Create more suitable portfolios.
  • Raise more awareness about the factors we need to keep in mind when building wealth.

Needless to say, I’ll shed way more light on this in the weeks, months, and years ahead.
